column4: Definition
It refers to the outsourcing of a company's logistics operations, such as warehousing, transportation, and fulfillment, to a specialized external provider.
It is a document that informs the consignee that their cargo is about to arrive at the destination port or terminal.
It is a systm that handles various aspects of trade processing, including manifests, cargo release, post-release procedures, export operations, and interactions with Partner Government Agencies.
It is a system used by the U.S. government to collect data on exports.
It is one of the eleven U.S. Department of Defense combatant commands, specifically focused on military relations and operations within the African continent (excluding Egypt).
It is commonly used in email correspondence and other written communication to indicate that a message is intended for a broad group of individuals.
It is the date when a unit is prepared to begin loading onto transportation assets at the point of embarkation.
It is a freight rate that is inclusive of all charges.
It is a system used to electronically transmit cargo information for shipments entering the United States.
It is a defined geographic area where a particular entity, such as a carrier or freight forwarder, is accountable for the safe and timely delivery of goods.

It is a major subordinate command of U.S. Central Command which serves as the Army Service Component Command for CENTCOM and is responsible for land forces operations in the CENTCOM area of responsibility.
It is a key operational-level organization within the United States Army's structure.
It refers to the precise moment a vessel or cargo shipment arrives at its designated destination.
It refers to the precise time a vessel or cargo actually leaves the origin point.

It is a crucial document that serves as a contract of carriage between a shipper and an air cargo carrier, acting as a receipt for the goods, detailing shipment information, and providing a tracking number.
It is a document that confirms a reservation for shipping goods, outlining the terms of the agreement between a shipper and a shipping line.
It is a surcharge added to the base freight rate to account for fluctuations in fuel costs, specifically the cost of "bunkers" (fuel used to power ships).

It refers to a group of items purchased together by a single customer and shipped as a single package.

It is a communication strategy where the most critical information or main point of a message is presented at the very beginning, followed by supporting details or context.
It is a document issued by a carrier or their agent acknowledging receipt of cargo for shipment.

It is a legal contract outlining the terms of hiring a vessel for the transportation of goods.
It is a surcharge added by shipping lines to account for fluctuations in exchange rates between the currency used for freight rates and the carrier's operating currency.
It is the process of selecting and assessing transportation providers based on a comprehensive review of their costs and performance.
It is a unit of volume used to measure the amount of space a shipment occupies.

column3: United States Customs and Border Protection
column4: It is the unified border agency responsible for managing and controlling the borders of the United States, including customs, immigration, and agricultural protection.
It is a document that provides detailed information about the potential hazards and safe handling procedures for specific cargo, especially hazardous materials.
It is a geographic combatant command responsible for operations in the Middle East, Central Asia, and parts of North Africa.
These agreements are trade deals between two or more countries designed to eliminate or reduce trade barriers, such as tariffs and customs duties, and promote economic cooperation.
It is an Incoterm where the seller is responsible for the cost of goods and the freight charges to transport them to a named port of destination.
It is a facility where cargo is consolidated (combined) or deconsolidated (separated) before or after being shipped in containers.

It indicates that the charterer (the party hiring the vessel) has the right to make a choice regarding some aspect of the charter, such as the quantity of cargo to be loaded or the number of ports to be visited.
It is an Incoterm where the seller is responsible for the cost of goods, insurance, and freight (shipping) up to the destination port.

It is an Incoterm where the seller is responsible for arranging and paying for the main carriage of goods to a named destination, and also for providing broad insurance coverage against loss or damage during transit.
It refers to a product, often vehicles or machinery, that is shipped in a fully disassembled state, as a kit of parts.
It is a detailed layout of how cargo is arranged within a shipping container, crucial for efficient space utilization, weight distribution, and safety.
It is the individual or entity listed on the shipping documents as the receiver of the goods.
It refers to a shipping container that is owned and managed by a shipping line or carrier.
It refers to altering the final delivery location of a shipment after the Bill of Lading has been issued

column3: Carriage of Goods by Sea Act
column4: It is a 1936 United States federal law that establishes the rights, liabilities, and immunities of ocean carriers and shippers for cargo transported to or from the U.S. in exchange for bills of lading.
It refers to the measures taken to protect military communications from unauthorized access and exploitation by adversaries.
It is a type of vessel that combines the features of a container ship and a Roll-on/Roll-off (RoRo) ship.
It is a United States territory, including the adjacent territorial waters, located within North America between Canada and Mexico.
It is a document certifying where goods were originally made.
It refers to the process of transferring cargo from one ship to another during its journey.

It is an Incoterm where the seller is responsible for arranging and paying for the transportation of goods to a specified destination, while the risk of loss or damage transfers to the buyer once the goods are handed over to the first carrier.
It is a fee charged by carriers to cover the costs associated with handling and maintaining containers used in the transportation of goods.
It is a designated area, typically within a port or terminal, used for storing and handling shipping containers, both full and empty, before or after they are loaded onto or unloaded from a vessel.
It is a document that authorizes the release and delivery of goods to the consignee or their authorized representative.
It refers to a shipping service where the cargo is collected from the sender's location and delivered directly to the recipient's location.
It is an Incoterm where the seller is responsible for all costs and risks associated with delivering goods to a named place (usually the buyer's location).
It is a standard, non-refrigerated shipping container used for transporting general cargo that does not require temperature control.
It is a narrow basin, either excavated or built, that can be flooded to allow a ship to enter and then drained to allow for inspection and repair of the ship's hull and other underwater components.
It is a fee charged by carriers to cover the costs of delivering goods from the port or terminal to their final destination.
It is an Incoterm where the seller is responsible for all costs and risks associated with delivering goods to a specified location, including import duties, taxes, and other charges.

These teams are designed to assist units during deployment and redeployment processes, focusing on enhancing the accuracy of processing, streamlining reviews, and reducing delays in the movement of personnel and equipment.
It is an Incoterm where the seller is responsible for delivering goods to a specified location, but the buyer is responsible for paying import duties, taxes, and other customs charges.
It refers to charges incurred when a container is held at a port or terminal beyond the agreed-upon free time, typically after it's been unloaded from a ship.
It refers to a ship's departure from its agreed-upon or customary route. This can be a voluntary and unjustified departure, potentially leading to a breach of contract.
These are items or substances that can pose a risk to health, safety, property, or the environment during transportation.
It refers to materials used to protect and secure cargo during transportation.
The rules and guidelines that govern the safe transportation of hazardous materials by air, sea, and land.
It is the Department of Defense combat support agency responsible for providing the global network infrastructure, communications, and information sharing capabilities for the military.
It refers to a single email address that represents a group of recipients, allowing you to send an email to everyone on the list at once.

Demurrage is charged when a container is held at a port or terminal past the free time, while detention is charged when a container is held by the customer outside the port or terminal area beyond the free time.
It is the United States federal government agency responsible for all matters related to the national security and the armed forces.

column3: Department of Defense Activity Address Code
column4: It is a unique six-position, alphanumeric code used to identify a unit, activity, or organization within the Department of Defense.

column3: Department of Defense Activity Address Directory
column4: It is an interactive database table that provides a single authoritative source of address information for Deparment of Defense Component requirements.
It refers to a plan focused on reducing the deficit by eliminating low-priority activities and generating savings through more efficient operations.

It is a worldwide, secure, and non-secure voice, data, and video teleconferencing network used by the Department of Defense (DoD) for command and control, operations, and other critical communications.
The electronic transmission of shipping documents such as invoices, purchase orders and bills of lading.

It is a surcharge applied by shipping carriers to offset sudden and significant increases in fuel costs, especially when a standard Bunker Adjustment Factor (BAF) is not sufficient to cover the added expenses.
It signifies the precise moment a vessel completes its voyage and arrives at its destination port, marking the end of its underway period.
It is a fee charged by shipping lines to cover the costs of moving empty containers back to areas where they are needed.
It is a predicted date and time when a shipment or vessel is expected to reach its destination.
It signifies the anticipated time a ship is expected to dock at a port or terminal.
It is a predicted date and time when a shipment or vessel is expected to sail from its origin.
It is a document that grants permission for cargo to be loaded onto a specific vessel for export.
it is a system designed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from various sectors, including maritime shipping.
It is an additional fee added to shipping costs when vessels need to navigate through areas deemed high-risk due to war, conflict, or other security threats.
It is an incoterm that signifies the seller's responsibility is limited to making the goods available at their premises.
It is a specialized shipping container designed for transporting oversized or heavy cargo that doesn't fit within standard containers.
It means that the shipper is responsible for the loading costs, and the consignee is responsible for the unloading costs.
It means that the carrier is responsible for both loading the cargo onto the vessel at the origin port and unloading it at the destination port.

It means that the shipper is responsible for the cost of loading the cargo onto the vessel at the origin port, while the carrier is responsible for the cost of unloading the cargo at the destination port.
It means that the freight rate includes the cost of loading the cargo onto the ship at the origin port and the consignee is responsible for the cost of unloading the cargo at the destination port.

It means that the carrier is responsible for picking up the cargo from the shipper's designated location including the cost and handling of loading the cargo onto the vessel at the origin, while the consignee is responsible for the cost and handling of unloading the cargo at the destination.

It means that the carrier is responsible for picking up the cargo from the shipper's designated location including the cost and handling of loading the cargo onto the vessel at the origin and the cost and handling of unloading the cargo at the destination.

It means that the shipper is responsible for the loading costs while the carrier is responsible for the cost of unloading the cargo at the destination port and delivering the cargo to consignee's designation location.

It means that the carrier is responsible for loading the cargo onto the vessel at the origin port including the cost of unloading the cargo at the destination port and delivering the cargo to consignee's designation location.

It encompasses all stages of the shipping process, from initial pick up of the cargo from shipper's designated location to final delivery at consignee's designated location, including necessary documentation and customs procedures.

It is an Incoterm where the seller is responsible for delivering the goods to a carrier (like a shipping company or freight forwarder) at a designated location, often the seller's premises or a named port.
It refers to a shipping method where a single shipper uses the entire container.
It is a document issued by the freight forwarder or their agent to the shipper of the cargo. This document is issued when the shipment has been handed over to the freight forwarder.

It is a program primarily associated with the U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) and its transportation agencies, like the Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command (SDDC). It streamlines the process for commercial freight carriers to become approved to transport freight for the DoD.
It is a financial document detailing the actual costs incurred by a shipping agent for a vessel's port call.
It is a standard unit of measurement used to express the capacity of a 40-foot shipping container.
It is a company that acts as an intermediary between shippers and various transportation services to move goods, both domestically and internationally.

column3: International Federation of Forwarding Agent Associations
column4: It is a non-governmental organization that represents freight forwarders and logistics companies globally.
It is a method of managing loaded cargoes where the first cargo loaded are shipped out first.
It is a method of managing loaded cargoes where the most recently received cargoes are the first to be shipped out.
This term signifies that the shipping line assumes responsibility for all costs associated with loading and unloading cargo at both the port of origin and the destination.
It is an independent regulatory agency in the United States responsible for overseeing and regulating ocean-borne transportation in international trade.
It is a U.S. government program that enables eligible foreign governments to purchase defense articles, services, and training from the U.S. through government-to-government agreements.
It is a common term that designates when the responsibility and costs of goods transfer from the seller to the buyer during international trade.
It means that the cost of shipping is included in the purchase price of the goods, rather than being billed separately to the buyer.
It refers to goods or cargo being transported in bulk, typically in large quantities, by various modes of transportation like trucks, trains, ships, or airplanes.
They are the representative and key component to ensure that strategic lines of communication remain open to provide flexibility for commanders.

It refers to a shipping method where a single shipper's goods fill an entire truck, meaning the truck is dedicated to that one shipment from origin to destination without any other freight being added.

It is a system used by the Department of Defense (DoD) for managing and procuring freight transportation services.
It refers to the main or central military command center where a commander controls and organizes forces.

It is a specialized agency of the United Nations responsible for regulating international shipping and ensuring its safety, security, and environmental protection.
These are set of rules that define the responsibilities of buyers and sellers in international and domestic trade transactions, particularly regarding the delivery of goods.
These standards ensure consistency, security, and efficiency in international shipping by providing a framework for container dimensions, construction, and identification codes.
It is a set of regulations designed to prevent the spread of pests and diseases through international trade via wooden packaging materials.

column3: International Ship and Port Facility Security Code
column4: It is a set of security measures designed to enhance maritime security by regulating and overseeing the movement of ships, crew, and cargo.

It is a central hub where military personnel coordinate, plan, and monitor operations in real-time.
It is commonly used to measure the actual weight of cargo, as well as the volumetric weight when calculating shipping costs.
It is a written commitment by a bank issued after a request by an importer that payment will be made to an exporter.

It is a document issued by a bank or financial institution. It assures the shipping company or carrier that the importer will fulfill their obligations, even if the original shipping documents (like the bill of lading) are delayed or not yet available.
It is a term used to describe at which date or between which range of dates the vessel should be at the load port ready for loading.
It refers to a shipping method where your cargo shares space within a shipping container with other shipments from different shippers, rather than occupying the entire container.
This is a formal request to allow cargo to enter Iraq without having to pay a levy or tax on it.
It is an inventory management principle where the last item stored is the first to be retrieved.
It is a method of handling goods where the most recently loaded items are the first ones to be unloaded or shipped out.
It is a shipment that was loaded onto a vessel but was not officially booked or documented to be on that specific voyage.
It is a document that grants one party the authority to act on behalf of another for specific tasks related to a shipment.

It is a cargo handling technique involving transfer of commodities to and from the ship using shoreside cranes or ship's gear.

It refers to a shipping method where a freight shipment doesn't fill an entire truck, and is combined with other shipments to utilize the full capacity of the truck.

It refers to the mechanical devices and systems used for moving, storing, and protecting goods and products in various environments like manufacturing and distribution.

It is the cost of transporting goods by sea.

It is related to the shipping of personal property for military personnel.
It refers to a cargo or containers that exceed the standard weight limit for a particular mode of transport or container type.

It is a detailed document that itemizes the contents of a shipment, providing information about the quantity, weight, dimensions, and packaging of each item.
It refers to the transportation of goods, typically in shipping containers, between two seaports.

It is a specialized type of ship designed to transport vehicles, primarily cars, in a safe and efficient manner.
It is a unique identifier assigned to a booking in the Integrated Booking System, specifically for sealift.

It refers to a bundled quantity of goods, often a collection of items, that are packed and wrapped together for transport.

The designated individual or department that serves as the primary liaison for communication and information regarding a shipment.
The designated port where a vessel unloads its cargo, marking the end of the sea transportation phase and the beginning of land-based operations.
The specific seaport where cargo or passengers board a vessel for a journey.

It is a surcharge that helps carriers manage increased costs associated with higher shipping volumes, congestion, and limited space.
It refers to a freight shipping method where a shipper's cargo occupies a portion of a truck's trailer, but not the entire space.

It is a program of activities, including inspections and assessments, designed to ensure that the quality of contracted services, purchased equipment, and institutional training programs meet established standards and contractual requirements.
It refers to the contractor's process for managing and ensuring that their own activities and those of their subcontractors and suppliers meet contract requirements for quality.
It refers to changing the delivery instructions of a shipment after it has already been tendered to a carrier, but before it reaches its final destination.
It is a unit used to calculate freight charges, particularly for bulk cargo. It represents either the weight or the volume of the shipment, whichever results in a higher charge.
It is the date a customer expects a cargo to be delivered.
It is an official request from a contractor to a contracting officer asking for an equitable change to the contract price.
It is a specialized shipping container designed to transport temperature-sensitive goods, like food or pharmaceuticals, by maintaining a specific temperature and humidity level.
It is a formal document that outlines specific shipping requirements and invites shipping companies to submit detailed price quotes.
It refers to the quantity of cargo, fuel, or other materials remaining in a ship's tanks or systems after a discharge or delivery operation.
These are vessels designed to carry wheeled cargo, such as vehicles and trailers.
This refers to the navigating lanes, both natural and man-made, in wide waterways (oceans, lakes…) used by large vessels to connect major ports and carry cargo.

It is a document issued by a carrier (or their agent) to confirm that space has been booked for cargo on a specific vessel. The SO serves as a confirmation of the booking and provides essential details for the shipment.
It is a unique two-to-four-letter identification code assigned to registered freight carriers and logistics companies by the National Motor Freight Traffic Association (NMFTA).

column3: Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command
column4: It is a unique Army command that focuses on the global deployment and distribution of military forces and material, primarily through surface transportation.
It is a crucial document in shipping that provides comprehensive information about the properties and potential hazards of a substance or product.
This is a detailed guideline provided by a shipper to a carrier or freight forwarder, outlining how a shipment should be handled and transported.
It is a method where goods, often vehicles or large appliances, are partially assembled at the origin and then shipped in components or modules to be fully assembled at the destination.
It is a document that provides detailed information about a shipment of goods.
It means that cargoes have been physically loaded onto the designated vessel for transportation.
It refers to a shipping container that is owned by the individual or company shipping the goods, rather than being owned or leased by the shipping line.
It is a crucial document that logs all events during a ship's stay in port, including arrival, departure, cargo operations, weather conditions, and delays.

column3: Safety of Life at Sea Convention
column4: It is a crucial treaty that sets minimum safety standards for the construction, equipment, and operation of merchant ships, primarily focusing on preventing shipwrecks and minimizing loss of life at sea.
This phrase is used on shipping documents, particularly bills of lading, to indicate that the carrier is relying on the shipper's description of the goods rather than independently verifying it.
This notation indicates that the carrier is not responsible for the accuracy of the declared weight of the shipment.
It refers to the process of transferring cargo from one ship to another at an intermediate port during its journey to the final destination.

These are used in the shipping and transportation process to link movement authority, funding approval, and accounting data for shipments of cargo and personal property in the Defense Transportation System.

This document is used to report issues with shipments such as loss, shortage, or damage to Government material to support the filing of claims.
It is a unit of measurement used to describe the capacity of container ships and terminals, based on the standard 20-foot shipping container.
These charges are levied by terminal operators for the handling of cargo at a port, including loading, unloading, and storage.
It is an electronic message that allows a shipping carrier to release goods to the consignee without the original bill of lading.
It is a formal document used to initiate the process of moving supplies or personnel, transforming an initial transportation request into a concrete plan for shipment.
It refers to the agreed-upon conditions between a seller and a buyer outlining the responsibilities and obligations for the delivery of goods.
It is a unified, functional combatant command responsible for global air, land, and sea transportation.
This is a U.S. Army logistics headquarters responsible for providing sustainment support within a specific geographic theater of operations.
It is the total time it takes for a shipment to travel from its origin point to its final destination.
It is a unique alphanumeric code, typically seven characters long, used to identify a specific increment of a unit's deployment.
It defines the standard physical units for tracking and managing inventory, such as cases, pallets, feet, gallons, or pounds.
It is a contract that enables the Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command (SDDC) to fulfill its mission by facilitating the movement of DTS cargo when ocean transport is required.
It is an additional tax on imported goods, applied at every step of the supply chain - from raw materials to manufacturing and the sale of goods.
It identifies the geographical area in which cargo is loaded on each voyage of a vessel.

It is a unique 17-character alphanumeric code assigned to each vehicle, acting as its unique identifier.
It refers to the amount of space that cargo occupies, typically measured in cubic units like cubic meters or cubic feet.
It is a broad term encompassing any type of watercraft, including ships, boats, and other floating structures, used for transportation on water.
This is a common term used to determine freight charges which indicates that the shipping cost will be based on whichever yields a higher revenue: the actual weight of the shipment or its volume.

It is a non-negotiable document that serves as a receipt for goods being shipped, outlining the details of the shipment and the terms of the transportation contract between the shipper and the carrier.
It is an additional fee applied by shipping carriers to cover the increased costs associated with navigating areas of actual or potential war conflict, civil unrest, or piracy.
It refers to the notification and payment process for customs duties and import taxes that the recipient of an international shipment is responsible for paying.
It is a computerized customs management system that covers most foreign trade procedures. It handles manifests and customs declarations.
It is a formal, structured document sent by a customer to a supplier or service provider to gather general information about potential products, services, or capabilities.
It is a wireless technology that uses radio waves to automatically identify and track objects by capturing data from a tag using a reader.
It refers to a scoring system used for awarding commercial service contracts, such as household goods moving, based on a combination of cost and performance.
